reviewText:
Now THIS is how ports are meant to be made!

Being a  obsessive  pretty big fan of MGS, I purchased the initial release of Ground Zeroes on the PS3 and 100%'d the game, leaving no stone unturned. The steam release for me was really a way of supporting development on The Phantom Pain as I didn't really think there much else I could experience that I haven't already done but boy was I wrong!

After 100%'ing the steam release of MGSV: GZ I'm happy to say I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this title to any Metal Gear fan or someone who's looking for a photo realistic, infiltration game with a lot of mystery.

Okay let's get the big obvious one out the way. You CAN complete the MAIN mission of this game in less than five minutes pretty easily but this is certainly a title of quality over quantity and considering the quality of this port? It's 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing stars my friend!

The official reasoning of the existance of GZ as a standalone title when it was originally going to be a tutorial intro for TPP is that GZ is radically different in playstyle to previous MGS titles and the team wanted to ease people in to this new style of stealth. Let's be real, that's bull. GZ IS however a great test in which the team received A TONNE of data and a lot of finance for development of TPP and to me that's great! They made a solid experience with GZ and can take further refinements to make TPP even better!

Ground Zeroes is a fantastic showcase of the Fox Engine's capabilities and how friendly it is for both developer and consumer! You take one look at GZ and you think Wow! VERY realistic graphics! Doubt my old spud of a PC could run that..." and here's the beauty of this port
date: you most likely can. While I can run it on ultra and at a over 60 FPS average

reviewText:
MGSV: Ground Zeroes is a third person stealth action game that is a prologue to the upcoming MGSV: Phantom Pain. In Ground Zeroes you play as Snake on a dangerous mission to extract to child PoWs from a US Blacksite in Cuba. You can approach this mission in two ways, get in and out as quietly as possible or rain hellfire upon the Cuban base, the outcome will be the same. As well as this main mission there are some side missions to complete afterwards which involve killing certain targets, finding intel etc.

Just want to point out I have very little experience with the franchise, Peace Walker (PSP) is the only MGS game I've played and I never completed it so I'm effectively new to the series.

+Amazingly good graphics
+Freedom to choose your approach to a mission
+Provides a nice introduction to Phantom Pain
+A fair few different weapons to find/unlock and use, each leading to a different playstyle
+Grabbing enemies for melee allows you not only to kill or knock them out but also to allows you to use them to attract other enemies
+The Island can be explored at any pace that you like, you can rush your objective or take your time and kill every last guard
+Stealth is very sastisfying but open combat can also be quite fun
+Several drivable vehicles
+When they work the controls are good, more on that later (Gamepad)
+Good AI that provide a challenge to remain hidden even on Normal
+Stealth mechanics are great, shadows and tall grass hide you as well as they should
+Very well optomized, my mediocre rig can run it on High at 30FPS

-Controller support is down right disgraceful. Firstly, the cursor doesn't disappear if you're using a control and it's stuck on the loading animation which gets rather distracting, I had to use a .bat file to hide it while playing which really is not acceptable. Secondly, I found that the game stopped responding to about half of the Gamepad's inputs after around 20-30 minutes of gameplay
-There isn't much story to the game and what little there is is hard to understand if you're new to the series, even with the backstory provided
-It's incredibly short, the main mission took me an hour and a half to complete (mainly because I had no clue what I was doing) and the side mission are also pretty short
-The bit at the end of the game, after you leave the Island is basically just an advert for Phantom Pain which made GZ feel more like a demo than an actual game

Worth Noting:
-There's a very disturbing cutscene that is most certainly not for the faint hearted

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing On Sale (7/10)

A good stealth action game that has amazing graphics, lots of freedom in how you play, great stealth mechanics, good AI and is very well optomized. The lack of content means anyone new to the series should definitely get it on sale but I'm sure diehard fans won't mind shelling out a little extra.

No drama, Just Reviews?

El K.

reviewText:
The enemy AI in this game is absolutely why I continue to play, and replay this game at least once a week.

When I play stealth games, I'm not interested in learning patrol patterns and sneaking around them with no problem. What I'm really interested in is an AI system that has context and situational awareness. This game has both. The main mission takes place during a hurricane, naturally this gives the AI reduced sight/hearing and what have you. I'll give a very brief example of the AI's contextual awareness.

After getting spotted and going into the, as I understand it, new slow motion 'second chance' system where you can take out the enemy that spotted you and go unnoticed, I shot the unlucky guard in the face with a suppressed weapon. Minutes later I intercept a radio transmission from the control tower the the guard I just took out. From what I can tell each guard is assigned a number 'Delta 1, Delta 2' and so on. Since the guard they were radioing was out of commision, they sent another guard to check on him. Soon they found the body.

In most stealth games you'd expect them to see the body and then either that guard doesn't tell anybody and searches for you, or other guards that have no idea what happened all know you're there. This game was different.
He assessed the situation and radioed back to the tower that he died of a gunshot wound and since nobody reported hearing one, concluded that the intruder responsible must be using a suppressed weapon. After hearing this information, the entire base went on alert with sirens going off all over the place and backup arriving just a minute later.

Most stealth games these days have me feeling pretty confident that I can hide around a corner and I won't get spotted. This is not the case for Ground Zeroes. If you want to get 20 feet inside this base without getting seen or heard, you need to find a vantage point and survey the area for a good 5 minutes, tagging enemies, trucks, watch towers ect.
This is as true to life as any stealth game I've played has come for me in the past 20 years. If you like MGS, this is worth checking out to get a taste of the Phantom Pain. If you like stealth games, there's enough here to keep you busy without knowing the setting or story.

This is just an example of how advanced this AI is for this type of open world setting. I'm a new fan of the MGS games and other than the Metal Gear Acid 'board games' for the PSP is my first time playing any MGS game. I can already say that without a doubt, I'm buying Phantom Pain when it releases and for stealth lovers, this is a lovely distraction from the wait until Phantom Pain comes out.

reviewText:
MGS Ground Zeroes, worth it for fans, maybe not for newcomers.

+ Amazing graphics
+ Fantastic port, 60fps, loads of settings in the options.
+ Very solid controls, great third person gameplay.
+ Very sleek and easy to navigate UI.
+ An astonishing amount of attention to detail.
+ The base map is designed beautifully for stealth.
+ 6 very fun side ops, using the same map.
+ Loads of replayability.
+ Great teaser for MGS fans for Phantom Pain.

- The main mission is roughly 40 minutes long.
- Side ops combined, one play through is about 2 or 3 hours long.
- The AI is very dumb, they give up pursuit very quickly.
- All the guards are telepathic, they instantly alert the entire base, they no longer have to radio in to go on alert like in previous games.
- The mouse sensitivity when zoomed in with a sniper rifle far too sensitive.

8/10, if you're an MGS fan, this game is essensial to the series, but get it when it's on sale.

AND FOR F*CKS SAKE, IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED MGS3 AND PEACE WALKER, YOU WON'T UNDERSTAND ONE F*CKING THING THAT'S HAPPENING. PLAY THE PREVIOUS GAMES.

(...in release order: MGS1 > MGS2 > MGS3 > MGS4 > Peace Walker > Ground Zeroes)

reviewText:
METAL GEAR SOLID V: GROUND ZEROES
REVIEW



After years and years, Snake is back on PC. After even Raiden making its debut on PC gaming this year, finally the main series is back. But this time is Big Boss himself, arriving for the first time on PC. But is Ground Zeroes worth? Itâ€™s almost certainly that you saw people on internet calling it a â€œdemoâ€ for The Phantom Pain, the main â€œVâ€ game arriving next year (which will be available for PC too). I had played GZ for 30 hours on PS3 and 100% complete(and you can see Iâ€™m a big of the series by looking at my steam profile too) it so I prepared this review! Ground Zeroes is the Prologue for TPP, presenting the new features on the series, like the open-world stealth, usable vehicles and new HUD. GZ have beautiful graphics using the new Fox Engine from KJP, itâ€™s really amazing, and for sure the illumination is one of the most impressive ever seen. The gameplay is smoother than the other MGS games, adding vehicles (In GZ you can use jeeps, trucks, APCs and can call for Heli support). You have now your IDroid which you can use to see the in-game map and to use other features like mission info, walkman, etc. The soundtrack is epic, and the cutscenes like in other MGS games are amazing, the ending is a good link for The Phantom Pain, the PC port is amazing, probably one of the best ports of the year, if not the best; and in Camp Omega you have all-new features like binoculars to mark enemies, destructible scenario in some structures and some collectibles. The only bad thing about the game is the short story. Depending in how you play it will take 1-2 hours to complete the main mission, so if you only play main missions on games donâ€™t buy GZ. But if you like to explore there are good 6-8 hours to complete all missions and 20 hours to 100% the game (which is a good time). The game have almost no bugs and now on PC there is support for beatiful 4K and modding! Kiefer Surtherland voice acting is actually good too. I think that he is better to play Big Boss as the game is darker, so, after all, itâ€™s a good voice acting(of course probably David Hayter maybe would be better).As this is a â€œprologueâ€ there is some features from the previous games that are not included, besides this adds more things. There is no Cardboard Box, knocking on walls, funny items, knife, etc. But all of those weâ€™ll be included in TPP. Camp Omega feels alive too! Soldiers are always doing something, like talking to each others about recent facts and eventually even tips for the objective. It's a cool system. And there are pretty animations. New animations and mechanics includes cool CQC moves, refined interrogation, and new and realistic crawling animations, where snake actually moves to where you are pointing the gun. The AI is one of the most impressive in gaming, the guards working and investigating, mostly on hard difficulty to have a real stealth experience (this series being one of the pioneer in good AI) And if you wanna catch up with the story for the other games, there is a section on menu for that! There is also a few collectibles to search in Camp Omega, including nine XOF patchs, that will unlock two extra ops (besides the four side ops). These Extra Ops are all for fun. It's a good tribute to MGS1 in DejÃ -VÃº mission, with a lot of challenges to complete, like finding and cleaning all MGS logos, and a lot of easter eggs, like playing with Solid Snake model from MGS1 and even Gray Fox model! And the other is Jamais-Vu, which adds pretty action to the game as you contro the cyborg Raiden, which some little changes to the mechanics, like running, and Raiden is a Cyborg. The four Side Ops are really cool too. They ar eunique, besides the fact that all of them pays on Camp Omega. There is an aciton-packed mission to destroy Anti-Air Emplacements, two cool stealth based missions where yoiu have some targets and a unique mission that you fire from the chopper while defending and then rescuing an agent of yours. The cool thing is that the agent is actually....  MR. KOJIMA!. All of those missions have highly replayability and there is a lot of things to find, easter eggs and ways to complete them. There is too another collectibles, like cassete tapes, and special weapons by getting some ranks in each mission. There are cool songs from previous games that can be unlocked and played in a mission, or even custom songs from your computer! There is now doubt that the game quality itself is unquestionable, but what about the price-benefit? Ground Zeroes price is actually good for those who are gonna explore the game and play all the missions, but if you are just gonna beat the main mission, itâ€™s not recommended. But after all, Ground Zeroes is an amazing game, with new mechanics that prepares us for the amazing The Phantom Pain next year. Besides story being too short, is a good taste for MGS on PC.

reviewText:
Barebones explanation about this game. This is not a demo!
In the eve of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, I'll be reviewing Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes because some people still don't seem to get it at this point (short version at the bottom of the review).

First of all, I've played most of the MGS games before this and I love them to death, so my opinion may be a bit biased.

Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a prologue to Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, like way back when there was a pretty short and limited Gran Turismo 5 Prologue but was still sold as a full game. That's not the case with GZ.

Bear with me for a moment, this game focuses on giving you a glimpse of what The Phantom Pain will be. GZ puts you in control of Snake (aka Big Boss) in an infiltration mission, but gives you the freedom to explore the mission area and tackle objectives as you see fit. With collectibles spread throughout the map, it invites you to step in every corner, watch enemy movements and memorize them, listen to soldiers' conversations, hijack vehicles, all adding up to the experience and helping you reach your goal. This main story centrical Ground Zeroes mission, can take from anywhere between 15 minutes and 1 hour or more since there's no time limit, also depending if you go full stealth or guns blazing towards your objective.

After you're done with the main mission, you unlock pseudo historical recreations of events prior to the Ground Zeroes mission in forms of Side Operations. These Side Ops have different targets and goals, from eliminating 2 targets in the entire military base, to destroying enemy turrets just before an airstrike. All of them take place in the same area as the Ground Zeroes mission, but you get a specific starting point for each one of them. Again, you're free to tackle your objectives however you see fit.

There are two more unlockable Side Ops which main feature is fan service. I could explain those two but why ruin the surprise? You can look online or in Steam for guides on how to unlock them anyway.

If you're a fan of the games and story, there are little nods to the past of the series. If you're new to the series, these collectibles and tapes will show you part of a great cohesive plot that has been developed over some great games, hopefully ending you with trying the rest of the MGS games.

All in all $20 isn't overpriced because the content is there. It is locked behind extras, but taking into mind how it's possible to put to sleep an entire army with a tranquilizer gun, then run over them with a tank, what you get is based on how and for how long you play. As of the moment of this review Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes comes bundled for free with each pre-order of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, so you get to experience this game just before the main course is released.

Short version:
Ground Zeroes is a prologue game, not a demo
Shows you the core mechanics of the upcoming Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain
Allows for replayability based on how you tackle objectives
Has side missions with different objectives, with many ways to tackle them
Many collectibles, some of them unlock more missions and story elements
What you see in the game depends on how you play and for how long you play
As of the moment of this review, Ground Zeroes is free with each pre-order of The Phantom Pain
Thank you for your time, I hope this helps your decision of whether getting or not this game. Have fun!

A HIDEO KOJIMA GAME

reviewText:
Negatives

-Story portion is very short as it's merely the prologue/demo for the full game, The Phantom Pain
-There's only a handful of other missions, and they take place in the same area
-Can't use the mouse in menus (a minor blemish)

Gray area

-Some of the previous features are missing, such as knocking on walls and shaking down enemies for items, though this doesn't seem detrimental to the gameplay, and may even be a positive considering how simple and tight the controls are (though it's been a few years since I've played the others, so I cannot make a 100% accurate comparison)
-Borderline being too spendy for how short the story portion is and the fact that all the other missions are in the same area and there's not many of them, but there's a solid amount of replayability regardless. This may or may not offend your sensibilities, but in my opinion it's worth the cost if you're not on a tight budget and find it on sale


Positives

-Gorgeous graphics
-Stable and well-ported
-Tight and simple but not overly simplistic controls; feels very mechanically sound; takes some cues from games like Splinter Cell
-No count-down timers or radar make for a more tense, fun, and challenging experience
-Useable vehicles
-Sandbox
-Non-linear setup allows for a variety of playing styles (i.e., stealthy, run-and-gun, etc)

All-in-all I give this a recommend if you find it in the $10-15 price range or lower. Though short, there's a few other missions that open once you finish the prologue, and the gameplay is rich and complex enough that it has a decent amount of replayability, the graphics are great, the sound is great, and it's a lot of fun.

It makes my Metal Gear... Solid.

reviewText:
Ground Zeroes is a prologue to Phantom Pain, an action-adventure stealth game. It only has one story mission unfortunately and it can be completed in just few hours. After that you have an option to do some side ops.

Ground Zeroes is great for rookies of the franchise to get familiar with the basic mechanics or for regular Fox Hounds to see some of the new additions in MGS V and put the story in motion for Phantom Pain.

If you already have or are planning to buy Phantom Pain soon, Ground Zeroes might not offer you much. If you want a taste of things to come, I can recommend buying this from a sale. Doing the sideops will give bit more longevity to the game. You can replay the missions to get better ranks or scavenge casette tapes that add to the story.

The Fox Engine looks and runs great on PC, if you want to test how your PC can handle the Phantom Pain, Ground Zeroes helps in that regard too since there is no free demo available.

Because of high quality and replayability of the missions, I think this game is more than just a paid demo. Everything from graphics, to voice acting and gameplay are stellar. But even with high production cost, the short length of story missions makes the game seem just a bit overpriced at full cost.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game, well I'm no hardcore legacy MGS fan and I couldn't give a donkey toss who Hideo Kojima is. I have fond memories of the 1998 PS1 MGS and that is about it.

I got this in a flash sale for about Â£3.50

The errr, game (I can't call it that; I'll just say 'mission') - can be rushed in about 15-20 minutes if you are running and gunning which is huge fun, but I was severly affronted when it ended... I actually said very loud and very clear; Really?

However, the depth to the mission while stealthing is huge and is really where this shines. Lots of nice options when dealing with enemies like neutralising, disarming, KO'ing, killing, interrigating, stabbing, chatting to then putting to sleep etc. Lots of routes, lots of options to the objectives. A small mix of vehicles, a surprising selection of weapons and some pretty decent voice acting - Even got Kiefer Sutherland as Snake... although he must say about 8 words throughout the mission in total. Its a got a lot of good things going for it.

The mission WILL catch you out plenty if you want to ghost it... this isn't a 'KO/Kill everyone on the map' type of game - As the mission progresses things change and that option / route you thought you left open for later, probably won't be, you'll be forced out of your comfort zone and forced to think and improvise - which coming my worlds of Thief / Splinter Cell / Dishonored - Is refreshing.

There are some 'grown up' themes thrown in to the plot, at least one actually hard-to-watch cutscene and a completely non-sensical story....

The mission is not worth more than a fiver though.... with the main game, mission, being so astonishingly, unjustifiably unbelieveably short. This is a bit like the Hitman: Sniper Challenge - A precursor to a bigger and proper, fully fledged game (The Phantom Pain obvs) which I'm looking forward to eventually playing thanks to this.

Saying all this there is plenty of re-play value, extra missions (rehashing the same 'map' / base used in different ways) and an absolute bucket load of easter eggs, secrets and fun to be had - So I'd recommend it to anyone into similar titles to Splinter Cell - but pick it up cheap... dead cheap.

reviewText: Though I will reccomended this game from a gameplay standpoint, this review is a critical look at MGSV as a product. While I certainly enjoy the gameplay Ground Zeroes offers, there is no reason this game was not offered as a free demo as opposed to a paid product. There is only one story mission, and it will take you a little over an hour to complete. I always assumed the complaints about the games runtime were an exaggeration; but they are far from it. This is essentially a 15$ demo with some quick and cheap side content plastered on to make it feel like less of a rip off.\n\nThe major defense thrown up by most fans is that there is content outside the main mission, which is only somewhat true. reviewText:
When I was 7, my father bought home a PlayStation One along with a copy of Metal Gear Solid 1. I spent hours, months beating that game, I remember every moment of it, from the epic intro to crapping my pants when Psycho Mantis did his voodoo â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and I've been hooked to this series ever since.

I've moved on from consoles, I built a PC and one of my biggest regrets was not getting to play Metal Gear Solid, the game that shaped my world view, the game that taught me how bad a war is.

And now, it's here. I cannot explain the multitude of emotions I'm feeling at this moment.

The game itself is just one mission in an open area, and now to add to Metal Gear Solid's fantastic stealth mechanics, you have multliple options and multiple paths to finish your objective.

reviewText:
Best enjoyed with all Markers, Enemy Presence, Damage Direction turned OFF

There isn't much I can say about Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes. People call it a payed Demo, and in a way it is. It has 2 Main Mission objectives, and 4 Side Ops. It certainly isn't worth full price, and recommended to be purchased during a Sale at around 75%.

Ground Zeroes is the Prologue to The Phantom Pain which is set 9 years after. However, Ground Zeroes is a optional purchase, as the events get explained in The Phantom Pain.

It introduces improved Graphics, improved Controls, new Animations, and the major change is the Voice actor of Snake going from David Hayter, to Kiefer Sutherland from the TV hit series 24 [love him or hate him, he's good at what he does!]

The Gameplay it offers is very well put together and staying true to the usual stealth Metal Gear is known for, while also being completely flexible to go in Guns blazing [which is great fun to do] with equal rate of success.

Essentially, if you haven't played any previous Metal Gear games, then in a Sale this would be a good investment to get a feel for what it's all about.

Genre
- Stealth / Action

Game Elements
- Stealth
- Combat

Average Playthrough
- 1.5 Hours

Liked
- Excellent Voice Acting
- Excellent Visuals
- Excellent Cut Scenes [as always]
- Great Music

Disliked
- Was a bit short, but replayability is there

+ Absolutely stunning visuals

reviewText:
As a huge MGS fan it's obvious I like this game. But what about those who never even touched an MGS game?

First off, this main game is short. Your first run on the main mission should take anywhere between 90 minutes or 3 hours at most. If you play just the main story and that's it, you'll be dissapointed. But if you like to complete side missions and have OCD, I feel you'll get your moneys worth with collecting all those XOF patches/cassette tapes, getting higher ranks, and finding new ways to complete missions.

As the for the gameplay, it's MGS at it's finest. Switching from crouching to crawling has never felt smoother, and it's actually hard to go back to something like MGS4 after playing this. And gunplay is great, especially with the new bullet drop effects, which makes you rethink about sniping someone across the map. My only complaint would have to be the cover mechanics. They're... quite awful to be honest. Hope they fix this in The Phantom Pain. Also no cardboard box. WTF?

The AI is pretty good as well. If you stand in broad daylight, it's obvious they'll see you 20 meters away, even on normal. And if you think reflex mode makes this game too easy, you're very mistaken. Especially when you get spotted by 3 guards and all you just shot a single shot tranq. Also, don't rely on regen health. Take too much damage, and you'll have to manually heal yourself with the marijuana health spray from Resident Evil. Realistic? No. But neither is eating rations that magically heal you after a point blank rocket launcher blast.

tl;dr version:

Pros are great replayability, lots of stuff to collect, gameplay, graphics, Hideo Kojima, and marijuana health spray.

Cons are short main mission, cover mechanics, no cardboard box, and too much water.

Overall I'd recommend this those who like to do everything in the game, have OCD, and want a great stealth experience.

Don't recommend if all you're here for is the main story. You'll feel ripped off. And hate water.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm off to attemp an S rank on the main mission. But killing the guards is so tempting after collecting all the tapes...

reviewText:
Finally, another Metal Gear Solid comes to PC, this time back to its routes of being a stealthy tactical title which is a far cry from the type of game REVENGEANCE was.

The stealthy aspect of Ground Zeroes does everything right. It's something that the whole series does well, so it should be expected though. As I have only had the experience with MGS 1, 2, Snake Eater and Revengeance, the melee controls seem fluid and faultless. All in all, the combat system and stealth are amazing, and I wouldn't change anything about them.

Now, I seem to be saying this every time I review a big AAA game, but these are some absolutely gorgeous graphics, whack all the settings up to full and you are looking at an actual piece of artwork. I couldn't believe how real the world looks in here. The character models, faces, everything, this game really shows off the power of PC gaming.

Ground Zeroes is the prologue for a future MGS title, Phantom Pane, although I understand Phantom Pane is going to be a much bigger title, I still felt a little miffed off that I was paying Â£16,99 for a game that only lasted two hours, and that's with doing the extra missions at the end. The actual main story can be completed in less than an hour if you know what you are doing....this to me was the only negative point from this release.

I had no technical issues at all, it's quite surprising to see a developer who mainly makes games for consoles, push out such a well-made port. A nice, steady, 60 fps the whole time playing.

The final verdict on Ground Zeroes; I would recommend it, but maybe wait until it drops on sale so you don't feeling the same as I did with regards to the game's length. If it wasn't for that, I'd say this is a must buy and a great game to test your rigs on.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Metal Gear Solid on PC... finally! So many memories of the franchise came back to me whilst playing this. Great to play as Snake in HD.. its been so long! The new fox engine is beautiful and it runs perfectly on max settings.

Gameplay is excellent, felt really smooth and controls are straight away simple to pickup. I am a strong believer in quality over quantity, this game being a pure demonstration as to why. For people that have been worrying about the short storymode, check my hours for the game. Personally I feel it has great replayability and with more challenges and tasks to do you will be finding yourself eager to get stuck in and try to earn all the accomplishments - like me.

Overall I am very impressed and am looking forward to the full game. Finally... Snake is here. We've missed you!

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid is one of the most revered franchises in gaming, containing some of the deepest and complex stories to have ever been told. Following the iconic Sold Snake, the series has maintained a strong consistency of quality and diversity, bringing us to a variety of different beautiful locations and establishing some of the best stealth action mechanics available. While we are waiting for the release of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, Kojima Productions have yet to cease development on Ground Zeroes, bringing the short prologue to the dynamic PC platform.
Ground Zeroes is one large camp Big Boss needs to break into and rescue two captives from Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker: Chico and Paz. If the player goes into the campaign a little stealthily, while at the same time not avoiding killing anyone when need be, they can beat it in roughly an hour.
The Metal Gear Solid franchise is well known for their lengthy and incredibly detailed cinematics, and this is somewhat similar. The difference is that thereâ€™s only two major cutscenes, taking place at the beginning and end of the campaign, along with another two very brief moments mid-mission. Unfortunately, youâ€™ll be stumped at whatâ€™s going on and who the characters are if this is the first time jumping into a Metal Gear game, but there is a rough breakdown through a slideshow available on the main menu.
Outside of the short main campaign, there are a handful of side operations to partake in. These give players objectives to accomplish in the same open area that are completely optional, but do offer a decent amount of variety. The short main campaign will not last you long, unless thereâ€™s a strange desire to go back and speed run the mission, and while these arenâ€™t particularly lengthy themselves, ranging from five to fifteen minutes, they are a nice change of pace. They also sometimes unlock plot related content through the cassette tapes, whether mission oriented or through Chicoâ€™s hidden set.
Gameplay is Ground Zeroesâ€™ strong point as the leap from Metal Gear Solid 4 is noticeable. Kojima Productions have crafted a sizable open area to move across, with soldiers that populate it and go about their daily businesses. While itâ€™s only one area and really only one type of grunt enemy, itâ€™s the mechanics that really show off what a modern stealth action titles should be. The controls feel a lot looser than they once did, with more modern implementations such as sprinting, jumping into a prone position, regenerating health, and much more. Enemy behavior is very different this time around, having an on-screen notification pop-up when an enemy has caught a glimpse of Big Boss.The more time spent out in the open, the more likely they will come to investigate, contact HQ to inform them of a suspicious individual, or outright call for backup. This somewhat ties into the new Reflex feature that is entirely optional for purists out there. Instead of gunfire raining down on Big Boss when spotted, he will have an opportunity to not only automatically turn towards the enemy, but be able to fire on them while in slow-motion.
Unfortunately, players did run into some hitches in the frame rate on AMD graphics cards, while Nvidia based units seem to run the game magnificently. This is a step up in the visual department, allowing for even more objects on screen and greater effects if your computer rig can handle it. Outside of the graphical options, the controls have also been decently implemented, as well. While itâ€™s still preferred to use a controller for how many different commands there are, the keyboard and mouse controls still offer an adaptation worthy of praise, and allows for a little more precision when aiming.
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a nice bite-sized piece of content that will help players get a good grasp on what to expect when The Phantom Pain is released.It retains the stealth features hardcore fans have come to enjoy, while at the same time implementing various modern mechanics that will appeal to an even greater audience. This also marks the first time Kiefer Sutherland replaces David Hayter as Big Boss, cementing the actorâ€™s place in the series. While it may only take an hour or so to complete the main mission that acts as the prologue to the next game, the PC port of Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes not only lives up to expectations, but surpasses them in creating an overly satisfying sandbox to sneak through.

reviewText:
1. Impressive Graphics (nice rain and lighting effects)

2. Impressive Gameplay and mechanic (The movement look , feel and sound right)

3. Decent A.I (Found most times when setting off the alarm, soldiers will either charge towards my location or fall back and regroup forming a group of 4 or 3 soldiers to back each other up)

4. Vehicles (riding the helicopter and driving any vehicle is awesome, especially the ability to knock soldiers out and take them for a ride)

5. Short....like a demo (The game is more of a tech demo, it does give a bit of a story leading towards Phantom Pain but there is just not enough there to keep you busy. The few missions there are do offer a bit of fun and enjoyment but being played on the same map as the story it gets boring fast)

6. Price (Buying it during the sale was great but I sometimes wish the game was priced $10 or should be included as a pre-order towards Phantom Pain, for it to be a standalone is just not strong and I find myself pacing back and forth wanting Phantom Pain to be released)

Overall Ground Zeroes offer a good taste of what is to come for the Metal Gear series, showing a bit of the gameplay and features that will appear in phantom pain. However for new players just entering the series it may feel strange charging $20 for a tech demo as well as create a bit of confusing as who is who and what is going on as the story branches off Peace walker.

If your a diehard fan of Metal Gear I would recommend getting this and go around looking for all the cool little items and points of interests. If your just starting the series I would recommend picking up Peace walker for PSP or PS3/Xbox 360 to help establish a bit of the story or wait for the price to come down a bit to $10. I enjoyed it and still waiting for phantom pain...............any time now........................................soon I hope......................hmm......any minute .....I guess not yet.....maybe now...................SNNNNNAAAAAKKKKKEEEE!!!!!

My Review of MGS V: Ground Zeroes
Check out the Entire MGS Overarch Story - If you didn't know it already.

Gameplay [9/10] - Probably the best Tactical Espionage game I have played until now. The Game Mechanics, The A.I, The openess in how you approach your Mission objectives. It's all top notch, I don't know about others but whoever did the porting of this game did a damn good job if you ask me. This is after all how a Port should be done and the fact that this game is just a preview of what Phantom Pain will be - I am just speechless (No literally I can't speak anymore, need to go to a doctor).

Story [8.5/10] - Now I wish I could have given 10 or at least a 9 here in this but that would be cheating, after all I am trying to give a genuine review of this game. This individual story is quite good, you have everything that you need to know provided in the back-story and casette tapes. The cutscene directions, the wonderful voice acting - all has been done near to perfection. However when you play this game for the first time (Like me) - All I knew about Metal Gear was Snake - I didn't knew who was who and all that stuff and honestly speaking - it's not quite easy to get hold of it either unless of course, you're a die hard fan which I wasn't - so what about us. Maybe someone else will provide you with a different solution but mine is simple, watch the video series (The Link I provided above - it will bring you up to speed on the entire MGS lore) and once again that video series if for people who don't know much about the MGS Story or they are confused in some parts. That will surely help them, it surely helped me - Now I know everything about MG ^_^ (Boo Yea).

Total Score [9.5/10] - This game for me is value for money, it provides hours and hours of gameplay - I am 12 hours in game and I still have to collect a few of the achievements that are left. So overall you get at least - 5 hours of gameplay if you're a player who likes to rush through things and over 20+ hours - if you're an achivement hunter and a completionist. This game sets a very good stage for what's in store for us - Phantom Pain (The name sends a shiver down my spine), that game will be epic. I don't know what others will do with this game but for me it surely will be one Hell of an Epic game, for me it will be one of the best games of 2015.

reviewText: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is basically just a glorified demo. Although it's awfully short, clocking in at only about 3 hours of gameplay, there is surely some replay value. How I replayed it was, the first time, I took down all the enemies lethally, the seconds playthrough, I did it non-lethally, which is slightly harder because they wake up at some point. The third time, I went in guns blazing. And no, this is not an excuse for me to forget about how short the game is. In fact, I have done this with Peacewalker and Snake Eater as well on the PS2. The mechanics and style feel very familiar which I like, the AI has been greatly improved, and this is the first MGS game to come out on pc, and I like that because keyboard is my preferred style. The graphics look top notch but not all the time. For example, the lighting got a little jittery reflecting to certain objects and the grass seemed like a ghost. Now here's the writing and directing. One word. Phenominal. I wasn't expecting it to be this great and it felt like I was watching a movie. Would I have expected this from an MGS game? Hell no, this was actually way too serious for a game like MGS because I always remember it being kind of silly sometimes and this was a little too serious. And when I mean serious, I mean mature audiences serious. I won't spoil it but you have been warned if you want to play this.\n\nThe voice acting is also very good but Chico might sound a little older than how he looks. The reason why you should play this game and the other ones from the series is because this is one of the smartest stealth games and you really have to use your strategy in this one. You probably have noticed all of the stupid AI stealth cliches right. Well, with MGS, you barely notice any of that. This game is also pretty challenging for beginners. There is no save progress button so be smart with your actions. Another great addition to this game is how you want to deal with the enemy. You can interrogate him into telling you where certain things are, kill him, or knock him out. I usually interrogate him first and then do other things. Would I recommend this game it you bought it when it isn't on sale? NO, this game is way too expensive at launch and now so don't buy it for a 3 to 4 hour campaign. If it's on sale you should buy it. I bought it from a third party site where it was around 8$. You should also check out the story of MGS before playing it because most new players might not even know even half of the things that are happening in this game and that can be a problem. This game had potential to be something greater but I feel like this was a little bit of a money grabber from Konami. Those are the two things I hate about the game, short campaign and the price. But I still recommend it though.

reviewText:
Back in the day, a game with this much content would have been considered a demo and given out for a free download from a fileplanet FTP or something along those lines... But, now we are in the age where people spend money to put armor on a horse, so, here it is.

Despite that, this game is amazingly well done, and there's honestly a surprising amount of content here. If you're the kind of person to go digging for extras and to play alternate missions, you'll probably get a few good hours out of this game. If you're just interested in the story, it's between an hour or two to finish. The story is also the typical confusing MGS flavor, with not much making sense, but hey, that's Kojima for you.

I don't regret paying $13 to get a taste of MGS again, since it has been a long time. I'm also incredibly excited to play MGS V after playing this, because the port was fantastic and the gameplay was great. The guards are much smarter here, and the world feels a lot more dynamic. If this demo is any indication, the full game is going to be absolutely fantastic.

On another note, I really miss David Hayter as the voice of Snake.

reviewText:
There are bombs hidden in lady parts. 10/10

*Edit, 22/12/2014*

In all seriousness, this game screams quality. It goes to show that although PC gaming is thought as a small business investment in Japan, Konami really have gone all out to make this game shine on the Personal Computer. This â€œportâ€ does not even seem to feel like it was created by a non-caring company that was only interested in your money; â€œBuy now, we fix it laterâ€, but a well thought out, and developed game that has PC gamers in mind. Port: 10/10.
This game runs extremely well on many/any computer, despite it being on a small map, this comes as no surprise, BUT the model detail, and the amount of AI in your vicinity at once is still handled well on older computers. The AI itself is quite smart on the hard difficulty, although on normal they do feel fairly dumb.
The price can feel demanding for people that have heard there is only 20 minutes of contentâ€¦Right,  many people have said this is not true, but as many others have also said, it can be â€œcompleted in 5 minutesâ€. Let me clarify, both sides are wrong. The Ground Zeroes mission, the main mission, CAN be speed ran in <10 minutes, whereas the entire game (for completionists), can range from 5+ hours. There is quite a fair amount on content in Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes and a lot of people seem to forget that.
The gameplay itself is very, very good. Although I, myself feel as if Kojima is keeping 99.9% of the gameplay mechanics (goodies) hidden well inside of The Phantom Painâ€™s unbeknownst release date. The way Big Boss moves, to the way combat is handled does not feel like a traditional Metal Gear Solid game. I am a long-time fan, and was at first sceptical about the way it looked from the trailers, it did not look â€œMetal Gear Solidâ€ at all. Instead, it looked like DICE and Activision had teamed up and taken over development and decided; â€œwe should make it appeal to all of the Battlefield and Call of Duty fans!â€ I could never have been more wrong. It DOES still feel like Metal Gear Solid, it just needs some getting used to. You have to remember the entire game itself is changing, the theme of the game has changed, the purpose of the game has changed. This is not Solid Snake. This is Big Boss. Playstation 2 players will remember how different Snake Eater felt compared to Metal Gear Solid, and Sons of Liberty. Big Boss is a different character, and has a different story. So what better to compliment his return to the game with new mechanics, a new engine, a new voice actor and a new tone of the series?

Overview:
Port: me, personally 10/10, but; 9/10 (Still heard some people are having loading problems)
AI: 8/10 (Normal difficulty is far too easy. Hard feels more enthralling)
Gameplay: 10/10 (Refreshing. Fast paced, slow paced. Stealthy or loud. Your choice)
Content: 8/10 (Not many missions, of course. But if you really want to 100% it, you 				may as well make a coffee and be ready for frustration)
Voice Actors: 6/10 (I used to love the codec screens, and the voices that followed. No, I am not whining like most about Hayter being gone. Solid Snake is DONE. It was a mistake to make Big Bossâ€™ voice actor Hayter in the first place. The guy is talented, as is Kiefer Sutherland, and I cannot fathom why the Japanese voice actor has been kept the same; but, Kiefer is the better choice. Why the 6, though? Because only select enemy soldiers have a voice actor. Most have the â€œPeace Walker subtitlesâ€ to serve as its way of giving you the information you got out of them. The only lines they have are notifying the command post of your presence, and shouting tactical orders, this is not fun, nor immersiveâ€¦It just lacks any interest in what is going on. Plus, another negative is Skullface. His voice does not command leadership, nor does it sound â€œVillainousâ€, it just sounds plain.
Environment: 5/10 (I could not come up with negatives nor positives for this, yes it is â€œopen worldâ€ to a degree. If you count Camp Omega, and Camp Omega alone as open world. There is much to explore, and much to learn about where you can place yourself in certain situations, but the map still feels the same as the time before. I trust The Phantom Pain will rectify this, and deliver what I hope to be a 11/10 experience.
Thank you for looking! Please do enjoy the game. If you are looking for a reason to buy it, you should not have to. It is worth every penny, and the series itself deserves every player, and it does not cost much? If you are still sceptical, just take a look at some YouTube videos.

reviewText:
I recommend this game, but VERY PRECARIOUSLY.

I have no idea about the back story of any Metal Gear game. All I know is that Snake has been cloned numerous times and is somewhat considered a super soldier. I do know that Metal Gear is all about informing HQ what is going on, and depending on whether you get spotted or not, can differentiate the level of difficulty you face at any moment.

This game by far, has excellent stealth movements available concerning mobility (running, jumping... yes jumping, crouching, and even creeping low on the ground). You can jump over obstacles, and even climb on a few. What you cannot do though, as seen in the Splinter Cell series, is climb up on pipes or hang over opponents heads to attack them from above. The running, crouching or standing, is enjoyable and sprinting feels absolutely right with the camera shake. You can even run and then press X to jump straight onto the floor into a creep position. I wish more games had this ability, or the ability where CoD had where you can run, then hold jump, and go into a jump position ready to shoot. When it comes to stealth, it is near impossible to hide in the dark. Hiding from the enemies line of sight is the name of the game. If you are seen by an enemy, they will get curious. How long they have seen you for will determine if they decide to investigate. If you are seen, enemies will not be afraid to rush you and possibly flank you. The enemies are always in radio contact, so take out a guy at the wrong time, and someone may be alerted. In-game, there are also vehicles present (APC, Jeep, Anti-Air Guns, Trucks) that can be used to create catastrophe.

These are neat features as most stealth games do not let you use whatever is in your environment to your pleasing. The driving is not anywhere near Need for Speed, but adds a great depth and choice to the game. The shooting scheme is done nicely, and when an enemy spots you, time slows down for a few seconds allowing you to quickly fire off a shot and hope to quiet the situation down. Enemy bodies can also be hidden or thrown once they are taken down. When you grab an enemy, you have the option to interrogate them for intel (enemy whereabouts, vehicle whereabouts, significant map locations etc...), choke them out (and risk having them wake up), or can choose to kill them. Killing them leaves a pool a blood and can be spotted by another soldier.

The sounds are great in this game. The attention to detail is much appreciated. When moving a search light, if you move it all the way to one side it stops at a certain point. Once it stops, it makes a slamming noise indicating you've reached the limiâœ of rotation. Speed doesn't matter (unfortunately), but it still makes the sound! When you get caught, the classical high pitch sound plays. The music is enjoyable and suits the environment.

One problem: THERE IS ONLY ONE FREAKIN' LEVEL. What a great game, but limiâœed only one level. There can be supplemental missions (such as rescuing prisoners) as the base is pretty big. It does not make up for the fact there is only one level. I feel besides this, a little more stealth could have been added to the game. I won't lie, I miss blending into the environment in a box. Would be nice if you could displace a crate as you moved.

RATING : 7.2/10

***The rating truly is at a 7.5-7.6 but since there is only one available level, this is what it gets as a complete game.

For future games : why not add in multiplayer or a local co-op feature? Multiplayer would be huge! The potentials are endless : PvP, PvComputers, or even cooperative missions with a few agents running around.

reviewText:
After years of deception, Metal Gear Solid series finally uncloaks before us PC Gamers. But how does the game perform?
MGS: GZ is designed to be more of a prequel to the true next installment of the series: Phantom Pain (don't worry, that game is also coming to PC). This particular game was made just to quench our thirsts and make the waiting a bit easier. More importantly, because of the dramatic shift the game takes the series by introducing open world and very open-ended gameplay, it was a way for fans of the past installments to familiarize with the new structure of the game.

Now I've seen many people claim this to be a glorified paid demo---I completely disagree however. The game offers a lot of side content, replayability with different approach to justify your purchase.

If you decide to just breeze through the main mission without bothering anything else, it would take only about 2 hours to finish it. However, if you plan to investigate the entire camp, find intel, rescue POWs, gather collectibles and do some of the side missions, then it will take you around 10 hours at least. This sort of venturing out of your way and exploring is definitely new to the series, which fundamentally breaks the linear level design and objectives of the previous games and works remarkably well. The open world provides more tactical approaches in handling the missions:  provides more ways of infiltrating mission area and approaching objectives. However at the same time the open ended nature can work against you as enemies are more spread out, are generally a lot smarter and if they see you then you are in for a tough firefight --- In previous games, this often led to many players restarting to the last checkpoint as more than often once you were spotted, it was impossible to go hidden again and you would eventually die. This time, you have the flexibility to not engage in the firefight for long and quickly become a ghost again. Another important thing to note is that the enemy AI is very dynamic--- They donâ€™t follow specific patrol patterns for long and if you â€˜disruptâ€™ their patrol, they will react in unpredictable ways. So, less memorization and more reaction is the gameplay paradigm that is enforced into the design and I for one gladly welcome this change.

So how is the PC port? One word ---Solid (no pun intended). The game runs beautifully across a wide range of systems and looks pretty good as well. While there are odd low resolution textures and detail here and there, but I guess that is what happens when you make a cross console-generation game (also available on the PS3 and Xbox 360) but it hardly detracts from the overall visual experience. My only issue with the gameâ€™s graphics is the obsessive use of blur. At times I feel like the game uses blur in the wrong situations and not in the right amount. For example when you point the gun in first person, it for some reason blurs the crosshair. The game also have some problems finding the right intensity of the blur for the relative distance to the background. Also, the FXAA used is poorly implemented and it just looks like it blurs out a lot of textures in hopes of reducing jaggies. For consoles I understand as FXAA is cost efficient in GPU power, but for PC, please give us an option to turn it off and use some other form of AA that does not blur the image. Even if some other AA was not an option, I would gladly turn off the AA here and instead using DSR (down sampling) to render the game at a higher resolution and downsize it, which works better than any AA out there anyways.

The controls of the previous games in the series always felt like one of the weakest areas, simply put--- they werenâ€™t designed to be effective when you needed urgency in your movements and combat. Thankfully, the controls of this game is very well designed. While many would understandably want to play this game using a controller, I decided to try it with the mouse and keyboard as it was a PC Gamer thing to do! After playing for a few minutes, I changed some of the controls to better suit my needs: Making the most of the extra buttons on my Logitech G502 mouse, I mapped many of the controls to my mouse as I feel I am much faster using the mouse buttons than many of the keyboard buttons. Again, this is down to the preference of the player which will vary from person to person. It was a bit odd to find out that the extra mouse buttons other than the right and left click not bindable. Another thing to note, the game does not alternative buttons for each command. Also oddly enough, the menu navigation cannot be done with the mouse, instead the keyboard WASD is used and 1 and 3 to change the menu options which I find it weird. These rough edges shows Konamiâ€™s inexperience with PC game design but they can be easily solved in a future update.

So that pretty much covers it. This is a small, yet delicious, slice of game that I have been waiting anxiously for. Like every delicious slice, it just makes you want more!

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid 5 Ground Zeroes is the successor to Metal Gear Solid 4. In a lot of ways it bares more resemblance to open world action games than it does any of the previous Metal Gear games.

The game takes place before the original Metal Gear and follows Big Boss on a rescue mission. The story isn't much to write home about given it's essentially the introduction to the Phantom Pain. Not a lot of the story is introduced to you, and it eventually ends on a rather unsatisfying cliffhanger. It is also unfortunately just a single mission with a few additional side ops that give you additional objectives while there.

Fundamentally the biggest problem with Ground Zeroes is not it's length but it's pacing. It ends just when you expect it to really get good and it leads into a cliffhanger and then a trailer for the next game. This caused a huge amount of drama when the game first released. It also feels very unlike previous Metal Gear games. David Hayter doesn't voice Snake, there are no codec calls and there's no fourth wall breaking humor. A lot of these problems carry over into The Phantom Pain so you should be aware of that if you buy these games separately.

The gameplay is all good though and it really blurs the line between action and stealth game. With hundreds of different ways to approach a single stealth mission. But it's not worth getting on it's own and the only reason to buy it is as a teaser while you're downloading The Phantom Pain.

reviewText:
Many people would consider what's on offer here little more than an attempt to charge for what should be a free demo and it would be difficult to argue with that point of view as their isn't much content here for the Â£14.39 I paid for the game on sale. However I believe what is on offer is very good if slight. The game contains a two hour story prequel mission with your typical MGS production that tasks you with rescuing 2 targets from a sandbox style prison camp. There are other things to do in the camp such as find collectables which unlock a set of bonus mission etc. After you finish the main campaign there are something called side ops, which change the time of day and give you different objectives to complete inside the same prison. Their are also a lot of lore filling audio logs regarding the characters in the game. Visually the game looks great, running at almost 3 times the visual fidelity of the next gen console version on max settings, and is easily one of the best optimised; If not the best, games of the year.

I would say if your a Metal Gear fan this is easily worth the asking price simply for the production values and being able to play in the stealth sandbox, others may want to wait for a sale before grabbing it.
My opinion is it's a great taster of what is to come and well worth playing.

reviewText: Everyone knows by now that this is more of a tech demo/prologue, so I'll be glazing past that pretty quickly. Ground Zeroes is a story mission and some cutscenes, and then after that you're encouraged to mess around and do some side operations. If you're a fan of stealth gameplay, $20 isn't too bad considering how well done it is, but enjoyment is going to derive entirely from just how much you like stealth. I like it, so for me, it's a good deal. Wait for the Phantom Pain, however, if you want more bang for you buck, content wise.\n\nMostly what I want to point out is that the port is pretty good. There's a frame lock on it at 60, but that's okay, considering not a ton of people have high frame rate monitors (I do, but I'm sure there's a way to break the lock). The game is beautiful and runs really well, even on maxed settings on a 680. Newer cards will tear this game in half, but was I ever surprised how well it ran maxed out. I'm sure there's still some tweaks to be made down the line and squeezing out even more preformance out of hardware with some optimizations, but for release day it's nice to see that a port isn't immediately in a sinkhole.

reviewText:
86 minutes to complete first time through, but what a great 86 minutes they were.

Yes the game (some will call it a demo) is overpriced and yes it has around the same content as that awsome, but free, Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty on the Playstation 2 all those years ago. But if you are a Metal Gear Solid fan I urge you to buy this game.

The game looks incredible on PC, at 1440p maxed it ran as smooth as butter with not one technical issue. The gameplay is fantastic, it's so much slicker and easier to control, but it hasn't lost the Metal Gear Solid feel. The main thing this game has done has fired The Phantom Pain up my anticipation list to somewhere near the top. Here is a list of pros and cons:

PROS:
- Superb gameplay, just like the other MGS games it feels like another level to other games of the time
- Looks amazing and is technically near flawless
- Lot's of unlocks, despite its length (side missions, weapons, etc)

CONS:
- Too short, even at a reduced price it's a bit much to ask
- It will make you desperate for The Phamtom Pain to release, you will want more!

I'm off to play through it again on hard. If the price an legth isn't something you'll get hung up on, get this game.

reviewText:
Ground Zeroes is a fantastic introduction to the game mechanics and story of The Phantom Pain. It includes a recap of Big Boss's story up until now, although as always a release-order playthrough of the Metal Gear series is recommended for a more complete knowledge of this game's sprawling and convoluted back-story. A large portion of the story of Ground Zeroes is told through collectible cassette tapes, along with pre-mission info and the logs of a certain spy. That said, Hideo Kojima's signature cinematic cutscenes make a return and they are better than ever before.

While Ground Zeroes may serve as an entry-point for many people into the Metal Gear games, especially for the PC crowd, I can't help but feel that Ground Zeroes is intended more for the long-time followers of the Metal Gear series. It is, after all an extremely short game, featuring one location that includes one story mission along with four Side Ops and two hidden Extra Ops. To shell out any amount of money for a game this short really requires some commitment to the series, considering The Phantom Pain is set to be about two hundred times larger, along with an online component and a base-building metagame. Fans of the series however, are sure to find many hours of entertainment contained in this small game - finding optimal routes, toying with the guards... endlessly replaying the single story mission in an attempt to sate the craving for that sweet sweet Phantom Pain goodness.

+ Open-ended gameplay where you get to decide how to tackle your objectives. High replay value with the ability to freely sneak around the game's limited open-world.
+ Some of the smoothest-feeling controls in a third-person game. Big Boss's movement is fluid and responsive, and mouse-aim is a very welcome addition.
+ The Fox Engine is unleashed from the chains of inferior console hardware to provide the premier visual experience of Ground Zeroes. The PC version features an extended view-distance, more dynamic lights, increased shadow resolution, screen space local reflections, improved ambient-occlusion, 4K resolution support and a bokeh depth of field filter that kicks the game's industry-leading cinematic sequences up to 11.
+ The game's minimum and recommended system requirements are exaggerated. Ground Zeroes will run on much older hardware and can easily maintain 60fps at 1080p on a medium-range computer.
+ Plenty of collectibles and challenges for completionists to take on.

- Very short game. More play time may be found in the Side Ops and Extra Ops, and through replaying missions.
- Lack of audio options and mouse-cursor support in menus.

Final verdict: 9/10 Pretty good...""

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeros is my first ever MGS game, and i gotta say that i was engaged in the game and its story immediately, due to the quality of the story telling , and the strong presentation of each mission in this game, leaving you with an exciting feeling, and an adrenaline boost before the start of any mission,

There's only little story to this game though, which is in the main mission ( Ground Zeros ), and you could finish it in less than 20 minutes, and i'm a new comer, but i still finished it in less than 20 minutes, which leads me to my next point, the lack of the main story is really disappointing, i'm not talking about the content of the game itself, the game is very rich in content since you can play various other missions, including rescuing Kojima himself, assassinations, playing as the might Raiden ( yes, he's mighty, screw the haters ), but i still wish the main story was just a little bit longer.

Overall, i will conclude my review with some of the cons and pros based on my personal experience with the game:

PROS:
- Amazing optimization, almost flawless, constant 60 FPS with everything maxed out ( please don't envy me ).
- Challenging enemy AI, their movements, response to suspicious movments, observation of the environment is almost perfect, leaving you with a since of challenge, and a satisfying feeling once you go past them.
- Great storytelling, voice acting, cutscenes, basically a very promising story to the full game, The Phantom Pain.
- Lovable characters ( oh really?), yes, i'm yet to find a dull or a disappointing character in this game, maybe because it's short, but that's what it is.
- There's more, literally, everything in the game is awesome.

CONS:
- Lack of story based missions ( they should've called this a demo, yep, that controversy again).

FINAL VERDICT:
A perfect 10 out of 10.

It's clear that this is just the begining of something amazing to come, which is The Phantom Pain, so don't take this review as a review for the whole MGS franchise, or The Phantom Pain, it's basically a review of a demo, a prolouge that should've been free, but oh well, it's still worth your time and money, and it will help you to get to know the controls and the mechanics of the full game, The Phantom Pain, Plus, you can upload your save files from this game ( Ground Zeros ) to the full game ( The Phantom Pain ) which will unlock some cool stuff!

REVIEW SUMMARY ( if you're lazy to read ):
It's pretty good.

reviewText:
Listen... listen.

If you're not already a fan of Metal Gear Solid, Ground Zeroes is not for you. Phantom Pain might be, but Ground Zeroes is not.

This is coming from somebody whose absolute favorite game is Metal Gear Solid, and while I would normally recommend it to anybody even slightly interested in stealth-action or sci-fi games, I wouldn't recommend they start with GZ. Why?

Wwwell, Ground Zeroes is essentially a tech demo and a prologue to Metal Gear Solid V as a whole. It was released because Konami wanted to put something out alongside the release of the PS4 and Xbone, but Phantom Pain wasn't going to be ready at the time, so Hideo Kojima decided to put out what he had ready so far. That was Ground Zeroes.

The main mission, the story, is about an hour long if you take your time. Outside of that, there's a few side missions you can do which, while they're pretty unique from one another (and pretty fun, too), are mostly just there for the sake of padding. There really isn't a lot here in terms of content. It's a game that will only give you as much entertainment as the time you're willing to put into it. For people who aren't already fans of MGS, that probably isn't going to be a lot, and it's going to give them a lackluster first impression of the series.

That's one reason.

The other, which is definitely pretty biased on my part, is that the plot simply takes place at a point in the overarching story that I don't feel is really accessible to people who don't already know what's going on. It's like an interquel, almost, in that it centers around a very important character at a very important point in the grand timeline somewhere between the rest of the MGS games. If you have little to no understanding of what has happened in past games, though, you're either going to feel very lost, not very invested, or both. You're missing out on a LOT.

Bottom line, if you're interested in Metal Gear Solid, find a way to start with the older games! I recommend release order. Join me in praying that one day we'll see some PC releases of those games.

If you are a fan of MGS already, however, and you haven't played this on console yet, you should! The complaint that it's really short is still very legitimate even for a fan, but as long as you understand what you're going to be getting out of it (which many people who had that complaint didn't), I think it's a very, very solid prologue and a really promising look at what's to come with Phantom Pain. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is tight and refreshing, all kinds of stuff. It is a reeaally fun game. There are a lot of other reviews that'll tell you the same things and in better detail, I'm sure.

That being said, I understand if you find it difficult to justify a $20 pricetag for a game you will mooost likely get around five hours of playtime out of. If you're not dying to play another, brand new MGS game like I was, wait around for Phantom Pain. Buy both at the same time. It'll feel just like the Tanker mission (like I'm sure it was supposed to in the first place).

reviewText:
Looking at the minimum requirements, you'd think this game will never run fine on anything but the top PC gear. However, the good news is that it turns out not to be the case. Mine is a reliable but old setup: AMD HD6950 2GB GPU, with an Intel i5-3570K OC'd to a safe 4.2GHz and 8GB DDR3 RAM.

The game looks gorgeous and still runs at a smooth 60FPS on 1080p, with most settings on Extra High, except for the various Filters and Shadows, which I left on High, as they seemed to cause occasional drops. Not a big problem, but if you have a better and newer GPU than mine, I believe you won't encounter the slightest issue at this resolution, as the stress definitely isn't on the CPU.

Speaking of another aspect of the port, the mouse+keyboard controls areâ€”for the most partâ€”done really well. If you can get past having to use exclusively your keyboard on the various menu screens, I'd say the controls are pretty intuitive once you have spent a few minutes on them. I also must say I've never expected to enjoy playing a MGS game using anything other than a gamepad, but I've been proven wrong.

The other advantage of having this game on PC seems to be given by the versatility and overall quality of the Fox Engine, which people have taken very little time to exploit in forms of texture and/or model replacements that yield results such as being able to play as Chico or Kaz against soldiers resembling Big Boss, or something as absurd as replacing the crows' model for a human one, which looks as funny as it sounds. Before long, we may have fully fledged mods that add up to the game or even become games of their own, one baby step at a time.

As for the game itself, it has one main mission which will take you anything from 20 minutes to 2 hours to complete, depending on your approach and expertise. Its function is to set the stage for the upcoming Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, and it's the only mission with relevance to the plot. Of course, there are side and extra missions which will keep you busy for a few more hours if gameplay is what you're mainly looking for.

I would recommend this technically very good port to any long-standing fan of the Metal Gear Solid franchise who doesn't mind a bit of redundancy in terms of overall setting on the way of some nice fan service extras. I can't particularly recommend it to newcomers, as it doesn't really give the best of ideas of what the franchise is about, and it might be a tad confusing for someone who hasn't followed the storyline.

To those, I would definitely recommend looking back to the older titles, most of which (excluding the rather important original Metal Gear Solid, in fact) can be found in the HD collection for PS3, PSVita and Xbox 360, if you have a console. Special mention goes to Metal Gear Solid 3 (originally released on PS2), which is a masterfully crafted installment that narrates the story of how Big Boss came to be.

A final aspect I would reflect upon is whether the current price tag is worth it for the average consumer. If you have slight doubts, I'd in fact hold off and wait for a sale, as the upcoming title will definitely steal the show and provide much more valuable content than this.

reviewText:
Ground Zeroes is a game that faced a lot of controvorsy for a variery of reasons when it came out on consoles back in March. Is it a prologue? Is it a demo? Is there enough there to warrant a purchase? Well, this question has three different answers depending on what type of person you are:

1) Are you a Metal Gear fan? If so, then this game is immediately worth a purchase. There isn't a lot of story in there, but it's all worth experiencing for yourself.

2) Are you only interested in MGSV, even though you've never played all of the previous Metal Gear games? Well, you should'nt worry then, because Ground Zeroes is a completely gameplay-driven experience after the initial 2 or so hours it'll take you to complete the main story mission.

3) Are you only interested in the main mission? If so, then this game is only worth it if you are okay with spending the money on a 2 hours worth of gameplay.

With that out of the way, it's worth mentioning that Ground Zeroes is a surprisingly fantastic PC port. The game always looked pretty on consoles, but the hardware-limitations kept it from reaching it's true height. Now, with sharper textures, much better draw-distance, AA, and shadows, and with the addition of depth-of-field, the game looks so much better.

Overall, if you're interested in this game, but not sure if it'll be worth it, then I'd recommend you get it anyways. What little story is there is of the highest quality, and the missions themselves are highly replayable.

Welcome back to the PC market, Kojima!

reviewText:
Listen... listen.

If you're not already a fan of Metal Gear Solid, Ground Zeroes is not for you. Phantom Pain might be, but Ground Zeroes is not.

This is coming from somebody whose absolute favorite game is Metal Gear Solid, and while I would normally recommend it to anybody even slightly interested in stealth-action or sci-fi games, I wouldn't recommend they start with GZ. Why?

Wwwell, Ground Zeroes is essentially a tech demo and a prologue to Metal Gear Solid V as a whole. It was released because Konami wanted to put something out alongside the release of the PS4 and Xbone, but Phantom Pain wasn't going to be ready at the time, so Hideo Kojima decided to put out what he had ready so far. That was Ground Zeroes.

The main mission, the story, is about an hour long if you take your time. Outside of that, there's a few side missions you can do which, while they're pretty unique from one another (and pretty fun, too), are mostly just there for the sake of padding. There really isn't a lot here in terms of content. It's a game that will only give you as much entertainment as the time you're willing to put into it. For people who aren't already fans of MGS, that probably isn't going to be a lot, and it's going to give them a lackluster first impression of the series.

That's one reason.

The other, which is definitely pretty biased on my part, is that the plot simply takes place at a point in the overarching story that I don't feel is really accessible to people who don't already know what's going on. It's like an interquel, almost, in that it centers around a very important character at a very important point in the grand timeline somewhere between the rest of the MGS games. If you have little to no understanding of what has happened in past games, though, you're either going to feel very lost, not very invested, or both. You're missing out on a LOT.

Bottom line, if you're interested in Metal Gear Solid, find a way to start with the older games! I recommend release order. Join me in praying that one day we'll see some PC releases of those games.

If you are a fan of MGS already, however, and you haven't played this on console yet, you should! The complaint that it's really short is still very legitimate even for a fan, but as long as you understand what you're going to be getting out of it (which many people who had that complaint didn't), I think it's a very, very solid prologue and a really promising look at what's to come with Phantom Pain. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is tight and refreshing, all kinds of stuff. It is a reeaally fun game. There are a lot of other reviews that'll tell you the same things and in better detail, I'm sure.

That being said, I understand if you find it difficult to justify a $20 pricetag for a game you will mooost likely get around five hours of playtime out of. If you're not dying to play another, brand new MGS game like I was, wait around for Phantom Pain. Buy both at the same time. It'll feel just like the Tanker mission (like I'm sure it was supposed to in the first place).

reviewText:
Alrighty, so Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes is a game published by Konami and developed by Kojima Productions, the game is the first Metal Gear Solid game to be released on Steam and the first MGS title to be ported to the PC in over a decade. (Whilst Kojima also has released Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance on Steam, which I also recommend for purchase, that title isn't technically a Metal Gear Solid game in the sense of name, howver is part of the same general universe)

Anyway so Ground Zeroes follows Big Boss, a Militaires Sans FrontiÃ¨res operative trying to infiltrate an American base in Cuba in attempt to rescue two individuals, Paz, a Cipher agent, and Chico, a former Sandinista child soldier. The base, known as Camp Omega, acts as the primary focus of the game and an American blacksite, meaning that the individuals inside, prisoner and soldier, are not bound by any American laws that would regularly be granted to people on American soil, as a result of the base's secret and obscure nature. A result of this black site status, torture and other inhuman atrocties that would regularly be restricted have been committed in the base, urging the rescue of these individuals even more. The game follows Boss trying to rescue Paz and Chico, using any means necessary.

Yeah, so the trouble is, that's the game, it's short and has a reputation for being such, it after all being the prologue for the upcoming Phantom Pain game due for release later this year. This release serving as a result of Hideo Kojima wanting players to have a peek into Phantom Pain before it's finished. The game is rather quick and the base game mode can be completed really quickly, and there is only one map in the game, the Camp Omega map.

However, don't let the game's length discourage you from buying this, it's a fantastic title, and the single best PC Port I've ever seen, the game running on highest performance being easily able to look better than the console addition, run better than the console addition, and play better, too. The game comes with many game modes to play, many weapons to use, and many tactics, strategies, and ways to play. The game has such a level of stuff to do after completing the base Ground Zeroes" mission that I'm still hardly any ways from "finishing" the game
